{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Format | image_file = Format zeitschrift.png | image_size = | image_caption = Logo of ''Format'' magazine | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 50,000 (2014) | category = Business magazine | company =[[Gruner + Jahr]] | publisher =[[News (publishing)|Verlagsgruppe NEWS]] | founded = 1998 | finaldate = 21 December 2015 | country =[[Austria]] | based = [[Vienna]] | language = [[German language|German]] | website = {{URL|http://www.format.at/}} | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Format''''' was a [[German language|German]] weekly finance and business [[magazine]] published in [[Austria]] and headquartered in [[Vienna]]. The magazine existed between 1998 and 21 December 2015.
==History and profile== ''Format'' was established in 1998.<ref name=pub>{{cite web|title=Format|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/global/media-solutions/media-search/media-factsheet-detail/?PARAM1=NW5FW1#.UlV3AGRJVgs|work=Publicitas|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> The magazine had its headquarters in Vienna and was published weekly on Fridays.<ref name=blei/><ref name=w3>{{cite web|title=Austrian magazines|url=http://www.w3newspapers.com/austria/magazines/|work=w3newspapers|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> The publisher was the [[News (publishing)|Verlagsgruppe NEWS]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Science News? Overview of Science Reporting in the EU|url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/conferences/2007/bcn2007/overview_of_science_reporting_eu_en.pdf|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=22 November 2014|format=Report|year=2007}}</ref> [[Gruner + Jahr]] had a stake in the magazine.<ref name=gj>{{cite web|title=World of media|url=http://www.guj.de/en/world-of-media/format-aut/|work=G+J|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Business Press in Austria|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers2/Natmessn.pdf|work=Helsinki|accessdate=8 October 2013|author=Charlotte Natmeßnig}}</ref>
''Format'' covered topics mainly on business, politics, culture and lifestyles.<ref name=w3/> The magazine also featured the views of bankers, trade experts and financiers.<ref name=esi>{{cite web|title=Communicating Europe: Austria Manual|url=http://www.esiweb.org/pdf/enlargement_debates_manual_austria.pdf|work=European Stability Initiative|accessdate=12 October 2013|date=12 December 2007}}</ref> One of its former [[editors-in-chief]] is Peter Pelinka.<ref name=esi/>
The magazine merged with its sister publication ''[[Trend (magazine)|Trend]]'' at the end of 2015.<ref name=tas/> The last issue of ''Format'' was published on 21 December 2015.<ref name=tas>{{cite news|title=Business magazines Format and Trend will merge to form one title: Trend|url=http://www.publicitas.com/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?no_cache=1&newsid=126190&title=austria-business-magazines-format-and-trend-will-merge-to-form-one-title-trend#.V_uZs5OLT6Y|accessdate=10 October 2016|work=Publicitas|date=26 November 2015}}</ref>
==Circulation== ''Format'' had a circulation of 68,000 copies in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Media Markets: Austria Country Overview|url=http://oldtelecoms.kondrashov.ru/world/austria.html|work=Russian Telecom|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=August 2004}}</ref> Its circulation was 50,000 copies in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |author=Anne Austin et. al. |title=Western Europe Market & Media Fact |url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |work=ZenithOptimedia |accessdate=8 April 2015 |date=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205131709/http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20%26%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |archivedate=5 February 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> The sold circulation of the weekly was 47,155 copies in 2009.<ref name=blei>{{cite web|title=Format – the Austrian Business Magazine (weekly)|url=http://www.bleispa.it/_uploads/Testate/Approfondimenti/pfdApprofondimentoT5321329app350.pdf|work=Blei|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In 2010 its circulation was 61,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Europe Media Facts. 2011 Edition|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact/2011/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202011.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> Its circulation in 2012 was 31,021 copies.<ref name=gj/> The circulation of the magazine during the first half of 2013 increased to 39,296 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=List of represented titles. Magazines|url=http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|work=Publicitas International AG|accessdate=29 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030071650/http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|archivedate=30 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The magazine sold 50,000 copies in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Austria: dominance of the tabloids|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/149419|accessdate=10 October 2016|work=Euro Topics}}</ref>

{{advert|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Graduate Business Forum |image = |formation = 1983 |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = [[Foundation (non-profit)|Foundation]] |headquarters = [[Fairfield, Connecticut]], [[United States]] |region_served = [[Earth|Worldwide]] |leader_title = [[Entrepreneur|Founder]] |leader_name = [[Jim Deveau]] |leader_title1 = [[CEO]] |leader_name1 = [[Siobhan Clarke]] |website = [http://www.graduatebusinessforum.com Graduate Business Forum] }} The '''Graduate Business Forum''' ('''GBF''') is a [[United States]]-based [[non-profit]] [[Foundation (non-profit)|foundation]] best known{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} for its annual global Graduate Business Conference, which brings together top business leaders, political leaders and selected student government presidents and vicepresidents from the top 55 MBA Business Schools in the world to exchange best practices on student government, Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and community service and to discuss the most pressing issues facing the world from a responsible leadership perspective. The Forum also organizes a series of regional meetings throughout the year.
The Graduate Business Forum was founded in 1983 by [[Jim Deveau]], a then MBA student and President of the student government at [[Columbia Business School]].<ref>[http://www.graduatebusinessforum.com/past-conferences/29-1983.html], "Ambitious Origins: How it all Began", Graduate Business Forum website</ref> Beyond conferences, the Forum produces articles on ethical and responsible leadership of the MBA community and engages its members in business school or community initiatives.
== Organization == The Forum is headquartered in [[Fairfield, Connecticut]], United States. It is [[impartial]] and not-for-profit and is not tied to any political, [[Partisan (political)|partisan]] or national interest. Its highest governance body is the Board of Directors consisting of business, academic and previous student government leaders.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Membership== The GBF is a community where leadership is put into action, where best practices are shared and where globalism is embraced by all its members.
Individual GBF Membership is restricted to elected Student Leaders of the Student Government Bodies of the top 55 MBA Business Schools in the world. Student Leaders are invited upon election to participate in the global activities, events and network of the Graduate Business Forum.

==Graduate Business Conference== The '''Graduate Business Forum's''' best known activity is the annual global Graduate Business Conference, which brings together business and political leaders with selected student government leaders from the top 50 MBA Business Schools in the world to exchange best practices, network, and debate the most pressing issues facing education and the economy from a responsible leadership perspective. The Forum also organizes a series of regional meetings throughout the year.

==Global Student Leadership Award== The Student Leadership Award was inaugurated in 1991 by the board of directors of the Graduate Business Forum (GBF) to recognize leadership, innovation and a commitment to the greater community at the graduate business level. In the past influential leaders, such as CEOs, prime ministers, presidents and royalty have bestowed this award upon a student or team during a commemorative banquet at the annual Graduate Business Conference.
Dave Chonowski and Chris Petersen, 2009 awardees from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, turned their winning idea into the MBA Veterans Network, a global community of military veteran students and alumni of the world's leading business schools. Their organization has generated significant interest from the business media and has since been featured in both BusinessWeek and the Wall Street Journal.
Member schools may execute up to two nominations for their institution.

{{notability|date=February 2009}} The 1st '''International Diamond Cut Conference''', held in [[Moscow]] Russia, April 23–26, 2004, brought industry leaders together to discuss [[diamond cut]], the factor where human intervention has the most influence, yet the least understood and hardest to evaluate.
The conference was hosted by Dr. Yuri Shelementiev, Sergey Sivovolenko, [[Garry Holloway]] and Janak Mistry.
Diamond cutters, grading laboratories, retailers and technology developers gathered to observe and participate in presentations and poster sessions. Topics covered included standardization of different cut grading systems; the grading of symmetry and proportion effects on cut quality; modern technologies and their application for [[gemology]], manufacturers and the trade; and new software for generation of new and more effective cuts.
Speakers included diamond cutters Maarten DeWitte, [[Brian Gavin]] and [[Gabi Tolkowsky]]; [[American Gem Society]] representatives James Caudill and Peter Yantzer; technology developers [[Garry Holloway]], Udi Lederer, Janak Mistry, Yuri Shelmentiev and [[Sergey Sivovolenko]], Octonus; and researchers V.K. Baranov, A.M. Bocharov, Michael Cowing, A.G. Golubinsky, [[Bruce Harding]], R.I. Ilkaev, Y.N. Rebrik, Dr. Jose Sasian, M.A. Shkadov and [[Iiro Suokko]].
The Second International Diamond Cut Conference, planned to take place in [[Lausanne]] Switzerland in March 2009, will now be rescheduled for a future date: The budgetary and travel restrictions imposed by the worldwide economic crisis caused this postposement.

{{use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Leonid Nevzlin | image = Leonid Nevzlin by Anton Nossik.jpg | alt = | caption = Leonid Nevzlin by [[Anton Nossik]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|9|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | other_names = | residence = [[Herzliya]], [[Israel]] | citizenship = [[Israel]] | alma_mater = [[Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas|Gubkin Institute of Oil and Gas]] | occupation = Businessman and philanthropist | known_for = | networth = | height = | website = }} '''Leonid Borisovich Nevzlin''' ({{lang-ru|Леонид Борисович Невзлин}}; {{lang-he|לאוניד בוריסוביץ' נבזלין}}, born 21 September 1959) is a [[Russia]]n-born [[Israel]]i businessman and philanthropist.
Nevzlin occupied various high-ranking positions at [[Group Menatep]] and its subsidiary, the [[Yukos Oil Company]]. In 2003, the Russia expropriated Yukos and began a campaign of persecution against its executives. In 2014, the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] ruled in favor of Nevzlin and other Yukos shareholders, calling the actions of the Russian state “a ruthless campaign to destroy Yukos” and expropriate its assets.
==Professional career== From 1981-87, Nevzlin was a software engineer at Zarubezhgeologia, an external trade organization of the Soviet Ministry of Geology. In 1987, he met [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]] and became a Deputy Director at the Center for Scientific and Technical Creativity for Youth (MENATEP), attached to the Komsomol committee in Moscow's [[Frunzensky District, Moscow|Frunzensky District]].<ref name=lenta>{{cite web |url=http://lenta.ru/lib/14159507 |title=Невзлин, Леонид |website=Lenta.ru |accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
MENATEP established one of the first private banks in Russia, Bank Menatep. From 1989 to 1991, Nevzlin served as president of the bank, after which he held other high-ranking positions, including Vice Chairman of the Board (1993-1996) and Head of Public Relations (1994-1996). Nevzlin also worked at Group Menatep, focusing on corporate communications, government relations, and human resources. In April 1996 he became Vice President of Yukos, in which Menatep had acquired a 78% share in December 1995.<ref name="lenta"/>
From September 1997 to October 1998, Nevzlin served as first deputy director general of the Russian news agency ITAR TASS, creating a plan to gradually transform it into a joint-stock company.<ref name="lenta"/><ref name="Charity1"/> In April 1998 Nevzlin became First Vice Chairman of Bank Menatep. In 1999 he became First Vice Chairman of the board of directors of Yukos.<ref name=lenta/> From November 2001 to March 2003, he represented the [[Republic of Mordovia]] as a senator in the [[Federation Council of Russia]]. From June to November 2003, he served as the Rector of the [[Russian State University for the Humanities]]. In 2003 and 2004, Nevzlin was featured on Forbes magazine's list of the world’s 100 wealthiest people. In 2010 his wealth was estimated at US$1.3 billion.<ref name="lenta"/><ref name="Charity1"/>
Nevzlin is a co-owner and board member of Haaretz, one of Israel’s liberal newspapers, having purchased a 20% stake in the company in 2011 for 140 million shekels. Members of the Schocken family, descendants of the newspaper’s founders, retain a 60 percent stake in the company.<ref name="Charity1"/> In 2014, Nevzlin founded the monthly Hebrew-language magazine “Liberal,” which publishes analyses of Israeli political life, communications and culture. The inaugural issue appeared in May 2014.<ref name="Reuters2">{{cite news |last=Davies |first=Megan |date=29 July 2014 |title=Nevzlin not likely to back down in Yukos fight with Russia |newspaper=Reuters |location=Moscow and Tel Aviv }}</ref>
===Legal disputes=== In 2003, following prolonged clashes with the Kremlin, Yukos’ controlling shareholder, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, and another senior executive, [[Platon Lebedev]], were arrested on charges of fraud and tax evasion. Both were convicted in 2005 following trials that were widely condemned internationally as procedurally flawed and politically motivated.<ref name="VF"/><ref name="International1">{{cite news |last=Buckley |first=Neil |date=19 December 2014 |title=Lunch with the FT: Mikhail Khodorkovsk |newspaper=Financial Times |location=London, UK }}</ref><ref name="Unfair">{{cite news |last=Waterfield |first=Bruno |date=25 July 2013 |title=Mikhail Khodorkovsky trial was 'unfair' but not political, rules European court |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/10202131/Mikhail-Khodorkovsky-trial-was-unfair-but-not-political-rules-European-court.html |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=United Kingdom |access-date=10 February 2015}}</ref> Khodorkovsky was found guilty and the sentence for tax evasion and fraud was upheld by the European Court of Human Rights for the same affair. Yukos’ assets were subsequently awarded to state-owned companies in a series of forced auctions. Yukos was declared bankrupt in August 2006.<ref name="WSJ1">{{cite news |last=Ram |first=Vidya |date=1 August 2008 |title=Leonid Nevzlin: The One Who Got Away |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/08/01/nevzlin-khodorkovsky-yukos-face-cx_vr_0801autofacescan01.html |newspaper=Forbes |location=New York, New York |accessdate=14 February 2015}}</ref>
Nevzlin left Russia for Israel in 2003. In 2004 the Russian Prosecutor General's Office sought Nevzlin’s extradition over hotly disputed criminal allegations against him related to his tenure at Yukos. The Israeli government rejected the extradition request due to insufficient evidence. Two members of the public who felt aggrieved by the government’s decision sued to have it reversed. They also petitioned the interior minister to revoke Nevzlin’s Israeli citizenship on the grounds that it was obtained under false pretenses. Nevzlin’s attorney, [[David Libai]], argued that the charges against him were the result of political persecution. A spokesman for Nevzlin stated in reaction to extradition request, "Amnesty International, the European Parliament, and the court in the UK, are only some of the bodies that have found that Russian president Vladimir Putin is persecuting Mikhail Khodorovsky, Leonid Nevzlin, and the other shareholders in Yukos, who dared to support democratic opposition parties and openly come out against him. Putin does not hesitate to make use of the Russian authorities that are subordinate to him to create false charges - in the best tradition of the KGB, in which Putin grew up."<ref name="WSJ1"/><ref name="court">{{cite news |last=Benaroia |first=Amit |date=15 May 2008 |title=Nevzlin beats extradition |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/nevzlin-beats-extradition-1.245914 |newspaper=Haaretz |location=Israel |accessdate=13 January 2015 }}</ref><ref name="Reuters2"/>
In May 2008 Israel’s Supreme Court found there was no evidence directly connecting Nevzlin to the criminal allegations made against him. The court rejected extradition and denied the motion to strip Nevzlin of his citizenship. Israel's interior minister and attorney general were ordered to pay Nevzlin’s court costs for this case.<ref name="Reuters2"/> Nevzlin was tried in absentia in Russia in March 2008, found guilty of several counts of conspiracy to murder<ref name=komm.sud>[http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1109205 Верховный суд признал пожизненное заключение для Леонида Невзлина законным] // [[Коммерсантъ-Online]], 27 января 2009.</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120909001040/http://www.rosbalt.ru/2008/08/01/509409.html Невзлина признали убийцей] // [[Росбалт]], 1 августа 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.interkavkaz.eu/reportages/nevzlin-nakanune-hodorkovskogo Невзлин накануне Ходорковского] // 17 декабря 2013.</ref> and sentenced to life imprisonment. Nevzlin called the court case a show trial orchestrated by Vladimir Putin.<ref name="WSJ1"/>
In 2014, the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] in The Hague, despite the Russian Duma having never ratified the treaty under which this judgment has been made therefore making a non-legally binding judgment, ruled unanimously that the Russian authorities had conducted a “ruthless campaign to destroy Yukos, appropriate its assets and eliminate Mr. [Mikhail] Khodorkovsky as a political opponent.” According to the panel, the forced auction of core parts of the company through contested bankruptcy proceedings “was not driven by motives of tax collection but by the desire of the State to acquire Yukos’ most valuable asset and bankrupt Yukos…. In short, it was in effect a devious and calculated expropriation.”{{cn|date=November 2018}}
The former Yukos shareholders were awarded damages totaling $50 billion – the largest arbitration award in history. As the biggest shareholder of GML, the former Yukos holding company that brought the legal case, with a 70 per cent stake, Nevzlin stands to be the biggest single beneficiary from The Hague’s ruling. The Russian government failed to meet the deadline of January 15, 2015, for paying that award. Earlier news reports indicated that the former Yukos investors would seek redress by asking U.S. and EU courts to seize Russian-owned assets on their territory.<ref name="WSJ1"/><ref name="Reuters1">{{cite news |last=Cohen |first=Tova |date=28 July 2014 |title=Nevzlin 'very pleased' with Hague court ruling on Yukos |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/07/28/uk-russia-yukos-nevzlin-idUKKBN0FX0SV20140728 |newspaper=Reuters |location=Tel Aviv |access-date=10 February 2015}}</ref>
==Public affairs and philanthropy== Nevzlin was awarded the Order of Friendship, one of the Russian Federation’s highest honors, for his efforts in supporting Boris Yeltsin’s reelection campaign in 1996.<ref name="lenta"/>
From March to December 2001 Nevzlin served as president of the [[Russian Jewish Congress]]. He was a key player in Jewish historical and heritage research projects, including the establishment of the Moscow Jewish Cultural Center and the International Center for Russian and Eastern European Jewish Studies in Moscow. Moreover, Nevzlin contributed to numerous other Jewish educational programs developed in collaboration with [[World ORT]], the [[Jewish Agency for Israel]] and the [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee]].<ref name="lenta"/><ref name="Charity1"/>
Since moving to Israel, Nevzlin has established the NADAV Foundation, which supports projects in Jewish studies and education, Israel-Diaspora relations and Jewish peoplehood. Its annual “NADAV Peoplehood Prize” has been awarded to such figures as author [[Elie Wiesel]], retired Israeli Supreme Court Chief Justice [[Aharon Barak]], and, most recently, Rabbi [[David Stav]], an Israeli Orthodox rabbi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=224627 |title=Jerusalem Post - Breaking News |publisher=Jpost |date=2013-01-03 |accessdate=2013-01-10}}</ref><ref name="lenta"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nadavfund.org.il/projects |title=Projects |publisher=Nadav fund |accessdate=2013-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125002925/http://www.nadavfund.org.il/projects |archivedate=25 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Reuters2"/>
Nevzlin created the Leonid Nevzlin Research Center for Russian and Eastern European Jewry at Jerusalem’s Hebrew University. He has also served on the boards of both the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Tel Aviv University.<ref name="Charity1"/>
In collaboration with the Israeli government, Nevzlin created a relief fund in 2004 to revive [[Beit Hatfutsot]] – the Museum of the Jewish People, located on the campus of Tel Aviv University, and was elected Chairman of its International Board of Governors. The NADAV Foundation launched the International School for Jewish Peoplehood Studies at Beit Hatfutsot in 2006, and the Nevzlin Center for Jewish Peoplehood at the Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) Herzliya in 2010.<ref name="Charity1">{{cite news |last=Cashman |first=Greer Fay |date=8 October 2013 |title=The Grapevine: 20th Anniversary! |url=http://www.jpost.com/Features/In-Thespotlight/The-Grapevine-20th-Anniversary-328188 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |location=Jerusalem, Israel |access-date=10 February 2015}}</ref>
Nevzlin has served on the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency for Israel and the Board of Trustees of [[Keren Hayesod]], the [[United Israel Appeal]], and as Associate Chairman of the Board of Directors of the [[Jewish People Policy Planning Institute]].
Nevzlin is also a long-term supporter of Israeli healthcare charity Ezra Lemarpeh.<ref name="Globes">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=הרשת החברתית: בת-ים בדרך להפוך לריביירה של ישראל |url=http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000988196|newspaper=גלובס |location=Israel|date=23 November 2014 |accessdate=14 January 2015 }}</ref>
==Family and education== Nevzlin was born in Moscow on 21 September 1959 into a family of [[Belarusian Jews|Belarusian-Jewish]] origin<ref>{{cite web |url=https://charter97.org/ru/news/2018/8/7/300554/ |title=Леонид Невзлин: Я много встречал в мире выходцев из Беларуси |publisher=[[Charter'97]] |accessdate=2018-10-02 }}</ref>. He graduated from the Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas in 1981, and earned an MA from the Plekhanov Russian University of Economics, majoring in management and marketing. Nevzlin has married three times and has five children including [[Irina Nevzlin]], chair of the board of Directors at [[Beit Hatfutsot]].<ref name=lenta/><ref name="family">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Семейство Невзлиных в Израиле разрастается |url=http://izrus.co.il/oligarhi/article/2012-01-18/16753.html |newspaper=Izrus |location=Israel |date=18 January 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> Through Irina, he is the father in law of Israeli politician [[Yuli-Yoel Edelstein]].
In 2014, Nevzlin acquired an apartment in the new, upscale Waldorf-Astoria hotel/apartment complex in the center of Jerusalem at a cost of 40 million shekels (approximately US$11.5 million).<ref name="WA">{{cite news |last=Bousso |first=Nimrod |date=27 June 2014 |title=Israel’s priciest homes: NIS 120 million for a shore thing |url=http://www.haaretz.com/business/real-estate/.premium-1.601605 |newspaper=Haaretz |location=Israel |access-date=2 February 2015}}</ref>
==Writings== Nevzlin is the author of the two books “Человек с рублем” (“Man with a Ruble,” coauthored with Mikhail Khodorkovsky), in praise of free-market economics, and “Public Relations – кому это надо?” (“Public Relations – Who Needs Them?”).<ref name=lenta/><ref name="VF">{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title=The Wrath of Putin |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/2012/04/vladimir-putin-mikhail-khodorkovsky-russia |newspaper=Vanity Fair |location=New York, New York |access-date=2 February 2015}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2008}} A '''Masters in Business and Management''' ('''MBM''') is a general category of "[[Master's degree|master]] in business" or "master in management" degrees, usually pursued by students immediately after completing a bachelor's degree (which distinguishes the MBM from the post-experience [[MBA]] degree, which usually requires at least three years of work experience). Common MBM variations include MSc Management and MSc International Management.
The MBM is open to graduates in all fields of the humanities, arts, engineering, science and business. It is designed to equip students with generalist managerial and leadership skills that will improve their practice and help them start a successful career in business management. The curriculum is therefore often very similar to that of an MBA, though the teaching and learning styles may be different in order to account for the variations in prior work experience.
The [[Association of MBAs]] has been accrediting MBM degrees since 2005 and has [[Educational accreditation|accredited]] over 40 programs at international [[business school]]s.

{{For|the [[talk show]]|Meeting of Minds}} {{For|the short novel by R.Sheckley|Robert Sheckley short stories bibliography}} '''Meeting of the minds''' (also referred to as '''mutual agreement''', '''mutual assent''' or '''''consensus ad idem''''') is a phrase in [[Contract|contract law]] used to describe the intentions of the parties forming the contract. In particular, it refers to the situation where there is a common understanding in the formation of the contract. Formation of a contract is initiated with a proposal or offer.<ref>[http://www.learningthelaw.in/2016/08/what-is-offer-or-proposal-under.html What is an Offer or proposal under the Contract Law?], available at Learning the Law.</ref> This [[Covenant (law)|condition]] or element is considered a requirement to the formation of a [[contract]] in some jurisdictions.
== History == Richard Austen-Baker has suggested that the perpetuation of the idea of 'meeting of minds' may come from a misunderstanding of the Latin term ''consensus ad idem'', which actually means 'agreement to the [same] thing'.<ref>R. Austen-Baker, 'Gilmore and the Strange Case of the Failure of Contract to Die After All' (2002) 18 ''Journal of Contract Law'' 1</ref> There must be [[Evidence (law)|evidence]] that the parties had each, from an [[Objectivity (philosophy)|objective]] perspective, engaged in conduct manifesting their [[wiktionary:assent|assent]], and a contract will be formed when the parties have met such a requirement.<ref>e.g. Lord Steyn, 'Contract Law: Fulfilling the Reasonable Expectations of Honest Men' (1997) 113 LQR 433; c.f. § 133 BGB in Germany, where "the actual will of the contracting party, not the literal sense of words, is to be determined"</ref>
==Concept in academic work== {{Contract law}} German jurist, [[Friedrich Carl von Savigny]] is usually credited with developing the [[will theory of contract]] in his work ''[[System des heutigen Römischen Rechts]]'' (1840).<ref>Friedrich Carl von Savigny, ''[http://dlib-pr.mpier.mpg.de/m/kleioc/0010/exec/books/%22199236%22 System des heutigen Römischen Rechts]'', 8 vols. (Berlin: Veit, 1840–9) online, in German</ref>
[[Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Baronet|Sir Frederick Pollock]] is one person known for expounding the idea of a contract based on a meeting of minds, at which time it gained much support in the courts.
[[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.|Oliver Wendell Holmes]] wrote in 1897 that a meeting of minds was really a fiction.
{{cquote|In the law of contract the use of moral phraseology led to equal confusion, as I have shown in part already, but only in part. Morals deal with the actual internal state of the individual's mind, what he actually intends. From the time of the Romans down to now, this mode of dealing has affected the language of the law as to contract, and the language used has reacted upon the thought. We talk about a contract as a meeting of the minds of the parties, and thence it is inferred in various cases that there is no contract because their minds have not met; that is, because they have intended different things or because one party has not known of the assent of the other. Yet nothing is more certain than that parties may be bound by a contract to things which neither of them intended, and when one does not know of the other's assent. Suppose a contract is executed in due form and in writing to deliver a lecture, mentioning no time. One of the parties thinks that the promise will be construed to mean at once, within a week. The other thinks that it means when he is ready. The court says that it means within a reasonable time. The parties are bound by the contract as it is interpreted by the court, yet neither of them meant what the court declares that they have said. In my opinion no one will understand the true theory of contract or be able even to discuss some fundamental questions intelligently until he has understood that all contracts are formal, that the making of a contract depends not on the agreement of two minds in one intention, but on the agreement of two sets of external signs — not on the parties' having meant the same thing but on their having said the same thing.<ref>Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., [http://www.constitution.org/lrev/owh/path_law.htm 'The Path of the Law'] (1897) 10 ''Harvard Law Review'' 457</ref>}}
The English contracts scholar Richard Austen-Baker has suggested that the perpetuation of the concept into current times is based on a confusion of it with the concept of a ''consensus ad idem'' ("agreement to the same [thing]") which is an undoubted requirement of [[synallagmatic contracting]], and that this confusion may be the result of recent ignorance of Latin.<ref>R. Austen-Baker, 'Gilmore and the Strange Case of the Failure of Contract to Die After All' (2002) 18 ''Journal of Contract Law'' 1.</ref>
==Use in case law== In ''[[Household Fire and Carriage Accident Insurance Co Ltd v Grant]]'' (1879) 4 Ex D 216, [[Thesiger LJ]] said, in the course of a judgment on the [[postal rule]],
{{cquote|Now, whatever in abstract discussion may be said as to the legal notion of its being necessary, in order to the effecting of a valid and binding contract, that the minds of the parties should be brought together at one and the same moment, that notion is practically the foundation of [[English law]] upon the subject of the formation of contracts. Unless therefore a contract constituted by correspondence is absolutely concluded at the moment that the continuing offer is accepted by the person to whom the offer is addressed, it is difficult to see how the two minds are ever to be brought together at one and the same moment...<ref>Thesiger LJ then refers to ''[[Adams v. Lindsell]]'' as supporting this proposition.</ref> But on the other hand it is a principle of law, as well established as the legal notion to which I have referred, that the minds of the two parties must be brought together by mutual communication. An acceptance, which only remains in the breast of the acceptor without being actually and by legal implication communicated to the offerer, is no binding acceptance.}}
In ''[[Carlill v Carbolic Smoke Ball Company]]'' [1893] 1 QB 256, [[Bowen LJ]] said,
{{cquote|One cannot doubt that, as an ordinary rule of law, an acceptance of an offer made ought to be notified to the person who makes the offer, in order that the two minds may come together. Unless this is done the two minds may be apart, and there is not that consensus which is necessary according to the English law - I say nothing about the laws of other countries - to make a contract.}}
In ''[[Baltimore & Ohio R. Co. v. United States]]'' (1923)<ref>261 U.S. 592, 597, 58 Ct.Cl. 709, 43 S.Ct. 425, 67 L.Ed. 816 (1923).</ref> the [[US Supreme Court]] said an [[implied in fact contract]] is,
{{cquote|an agreement ... founded upon a meeting of minds, which, although not embodied in an express contract, is inferred, as a fact, from conduct of the parties showing, in the light of the surrounding circumstances, their tacit understanding.}}
The [[reasoning]] is that a party should not be held to a [[contract]] that they were not even aware existed.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} A mutual [[promise]] between friends over simple personal matters should not be a situation where [[legal remedy|legal remedies]] are to be used. Equally, any such agreement where the obligation is primarily a [[moral obligation|moral]] one rather than a legal one should not be enforceable. It is only when all parties involved are aware of the formation of a ''legal obligation'' is there a meeting of the minds.
However, the awareness of a legal obligation is established, not through each party's subjective understanding of the terms, but on "objective indicators," based on what each party said and did.<ref>{{cite web | title = Texas Contract law | url = http://www.gaddywells.com/TEXAS_CONTRACT_LAW.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Ward v. Williams, Court of Appeals of Arkansas | url = http://courts.arkansas.gov/opinions/2002b/20021204/ca011209.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721032945/http://courts.arkansas.gov/opinions/2002b/20021204/ca011209.html | archivedate = 2011-07-21 | df = }}</ref>
Under the '''formalist theory of contract''', every contract must have six elements: [[Offer and acceptance#Offer|offer]], [[Offer and acceptance#Acceptance|acceptance]], [[consideration]], ''meeting of the minds'', [[Capacity (law)|capacity]] and [[legality]]. Many other contracts, but not all types of contracts, also must be in writing and be signed by the responsible party, in an element called '''form'''. {{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}
==Vices of consent== Mutual assent is vitiated by actions such as [[fraud]], [[undue influence]], [[duress]] (see [[per minas]]), [[mutual mistake]], or [[misrepresentation]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} This may render a contract [[Void (law)|void]] or [[unenforceable]].

{{Infobox person | name = Michael Cordúa | image = | imagesize = 120px | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = 1961 | birth_place =[[Managua]], [[Nicaragua]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[restaurateur]], [[entrepreneur]] | nationality = [[American people|American]] | footnotes = }} '''Michael Cordúa''' (born 1961) is a [[Nicaraguan]]-born [[Nicaraguan American|American]] [[restaurateur]], [[entrepreneur]], former owner of Cordúa Restaurants, and award-winning self-taught [[chef]].<ref name="HC">{{cite news|title=Professional and Personal Background of Michael J. Cordua |url=http://www.houstonhispanicchamber.com/hhcc/MICHAEL_J_CORD%C3%9AA_EN.asp?SnID=2 |work=Houston Hispanic Chambers of Commerce |accessdate=2007-10-21 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Cordúa is the former owner of six restaurants in the [[Houston]], [[Texas]] area.<ref>{{cite news|title=About Cordúa Restaurants |url=http://www.cordua.com/cordua.cfm?a=cms,c,29,5 |work=Cordua.com |accessdate=2007-10-21 |quote=...Michael J. Cordúa, restaurateur and former owner of Cordúa Restaurants... Today, he is the former owner Houston area restaurants. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623213118/http://www.cordua.com/cordua.cfm?a=cms%2Cc%2C29%2C5 |archivedate=2007-06-23 |df= }}</ref> He was the first to introduce Houston to [[Latin American cuisine]] that was not Mexican.<ref name="BA">{{cite news|title=Best South American Restaurant (2005) |url=http://bestof.houstonpress.com/bestof/award.php?award=42146 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070623014122/http://bestof.houstonpress.com/bestof/award.php?award=42146 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-06-23 |work=Houston Press |accessdate=2007-10-21 |quote=...Nicaraguan-born chef Michael Cordua was the first to introduce Houston to South American cuisine when, in 1988, he opened his first Churrascos. }}</ref>
==Personal life== Cordúa was born in [[Managua]], [[Nicaragua]] and later moved to Houston, Texas. He graduated with a degree in [[Economic]]s and [[Finance]] from [[Texas A&M University]] in 1980.<ref name="AMC">{{cite news|title=About Michael Cordua |url=http://www.cordua.com/cordua.cfm?a=cms,c,30,5,29 |work=Cordua.com |accessdate=2007-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817055151/http://www.cordua.com/cordua.cfm?a=cms%2Cc%2C30%2C5%2C29 |archivedate=2007-08-17 |df= }}</ref> Cordúa worked for a Houston shipping firm until it was liquidated in the late 1980s. After arriving in Houston, Cordúa taught himself to cook, he has said "The whole reason I got into cooking was because I missed the foods from home".<ref>{{cite news|title=About the Chef: Michael Cordua |url=http://www.squaremeals.org/vgn/tda/files/2348/8688_Healthy_Helpings.pdf |work=SquareMeals.org |pages=9 |accessdate=2007-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009161541/http://www.squaremeals.org/vgn/tda/files/2348/8688_Healthy_Helpings.pdf |archivedate=2006-10-09 |df= }}</ref>
He was named honorary consul of Nicaragua in Houston in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|first=Johnny |last=Cajina |title=Nicas discuten Cafta en Houston |url=http://www-ni.laprensa.com.ni/archivo/2004/agosto/08/nacionales/nacionales-20040808-05.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717011826/http://www-ni.laprensa.com.ni/archivo/2004/agosto/08/nacionales/nacionales-20040808-05.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-17 |work=La Prensa |accessdate=2007-10-21 |language=Spanish }}</ref> Cordúa married his Nicaraguan sweetheart Lucia in 1980 and has 4 children David, Michelle, Elisa, and Cristina.<ref name="HC"/>
==Career== Cordúa, with inspiration from his uncle's restaurant in Managua and despite having no previous experience in the restaurant business, opened his first 130-seat restaurant, ''Churrascos'', on August 8, 1988.<ref name="AMC"/> Churrascos was an upscale South American-style restaurant. Four months in, Cordúa was ready to give up due to the restaurant losing money. Many critics, such as the [[New York Times]], praised the new restaurant and in 1989 Churrascos was listed in [[Esquire magazine]]'s "Best New Restaurants in America".<ref>{{cite news|first=Ron |last=Ruggles |title=Americas' fare unites 'continental' divide - international cuisine |url=http://calbears.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3190/is_n42_v27/ai_14567673 |work=Nation's Restaurant News |pages=1 |accessdate=2007-10-21 |year=1993 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Fred Smith, a banker from First National Bank, decided to help him expand after eating at his restaurant. Cordúa took the help and opened a second Churrascos near the downtown Houston area.<ref>{{cite news | first=Claire | last=Poole |title=Pass the Chimichurri - Michael Cordua, owner of Churrascos talks of rising popularity of "Nuevo Latino" cuisine | year=1993 |url =http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0BEK/is_11_7/ai_56899206/pg_1 | work =Latin Trade | pages = 1| accessdate = 2007-10-21}}</ref> The second 175-seat Churrascos was opened in 1990 and emphasized a Central American [[churrasco]] that made up half of its sales. In 1997 Cordúa opened a third Churrascos in [[Chicago]]. It received great reviews from [[critics]], however, after 8 months it closed down when Cordúas partner backed out.<ref>{{cite news | first=Claire | last=Poole |title=Pass the Chimichurri - Michael Cordua, owner of Churrascos talks of rising popularity of "Nuevo Latino" cuisine | year=1993 |url =http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0BEK/is_11_7/ai_56899206/pg_2 | work =Latin Trade | pages = 2 | accessdate = 2007-10-21}}</ref>
Cordúa went on to open 3 other [[restaurant]]s; Américas in 1993, Amazón Grill in 1999 (2 locations) and Artista in 2002, all of which have received various awards.<ref name="AMC"/> Cordúa opened another location for his Américas restaurant in 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Cordúa Wins Big at 14th Annual Houston Culinary Awards |url=http://www.thewoodlandscvb.com/news/_2010/10-October/October14americas.asp |publisher=The Woodlands Convention and Visitors Bureau |accessdate=22 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222201444/http://thewoodlandscvb.com/news/_2010/10-October/October14americas.asp |archivedate=22 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> and also owns a [[catering]] company, Cordúa catering.<ref>{{cite news |title=Best New Chefs (1994): Michael Cordua |url =http://www.foodandwine.com/bestnewchefs/?year=1994&chef=5C80EAAE-32FF-41CE-972B9B30E9487B37 | work =Food and Wine | accessdate = 2007-10-21}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Cordúa and his restaurants have received much recognition and many awards throughout the years. He was named by [[Food & Wine]] as one of America's ''"Top Ten Chefs"'' and is received the Robert Mondavi Award for Culinary Excellence in 1994.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chef Michael Cordua |url=http://www.txbeef.org/chef.php3?993744620 |work=TxBeef.org |accessdate=2007-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018085327/http://txbeef.org/chef.php3?993744620 |archivedate=2007-10-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Michael Cordua |url=http://www.texaswineandfood.org/participant_details.php?pid=1181&ptid=6 |work=Texas Wine and Foods |accessdate=2007-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070304021657/http://www.texaswineandfood.org/participant_details.php?pid=1181&ptid=6 |archivedate=2007-03-04 |df= }}</ref> His restaurant, Churrascos, was named Best South American Restaurant by the [[Houston Press]] in 2005.<ref name="BA"/>

{{Infobox company | name = Our Generation Speaks | logo = | type = Non-profit Organization | founded = 2014 in [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] | founder = [[Ohad Elhelo]] | hq_location_city = [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] | website = [http://www.ogspeaks.com www.ogspeaks.com] }} '''Our Generation Speaks''' ('''OGS''') is a fellowship program and startup incubator whose mіѕѕіоn іѕ to bring together young [[Israelis|Israeli]] and [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] leaders through entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ogspeaks.com/about-ogs|title=Our Generation Speaks|publisher=}}</ref> OGS works in partnership with the [[Heller School for Social Policy and Management]] ([[Brandeis University]]) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://heller.brandeis.edu/about/ourgenerationspeaks/|title=Our Generation Speaks – The Heller School at Brandeis University|publisher=}}</ref> and [[MassChallenge]] <ref name=":0">{{cite web|last1=Kirsner|first1=Scott|title=Can entrepreneurship bridge the Israeli-Palestinian gap?|url=http://www.betaboston.com/news/2016/03/10/can-enterpeneurship-bridge-the-israeli-palestinian-gap/|publisher=The Boston Globe - BetaBoston|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref> to give OGS Fellows the tools to develop businesses that generate significant social and economic value in the [[Middle East]].
== Structure == OGS teaches business development, financial management, marketing strategy, and conflict-resolution to young adults aged 21–30. The fellowship runs over the course of three months in [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] and includes daily classes taught by Brandeis University professors, one-on-one mentoring, and workshops. During the summer, the fellows work in teams to build sustainable businesses that will benefit their home communities. The fellowship operates entirely in English and provides each group of fellows with the skills and network to enact change in their communities. Each business developed through OGS receives seed funding at the end of the fellowship to aid in their launch and operations upon return to Israel and Palestine.
OGS Fellows remain connected through the OGS Alumni Organization, which plans a number of annual activities, including group trips in Israel and Palestine, meetings with local leaders, and trainings focused on career and leadership development. The organization will host an annual conference for current fellowship participants and the growing group of alumni over time.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|title=Our Work|url=http://www.ogspeaks.com|website=Our Generation Speaks|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>
The OGS Fellows are exceptional young adults from both Israel and Palestine. OGS uses entrepreneurship to bring together people from these communities, which in turn works toward building trust and enacting social and economic change. Each year, OGS aims to maintain a 1:1 ratio of Israeli and Palestinians, as well as female and male fellows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/his-generation-speaks-qa-with-social-entrepreneur_us_585883a0e4b0d5f48e165242|title=Their Generation Speaks: Q&A With Social Entrepreneur, Ohad Elhelo|first=Yuval|last=Rabin|date=19 December 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
The fellowship is fully funded for the fellows.
== History == Our Gеnеrаtіоn Speaks wаѕ fоundеd by Brandeis University student [[Ohad Elhelo]] in 2014. Since its founding, OGS has received financial support and advising from оvеr fіftу independent American, Pаlеѕtіnіаn, and Iѕrаеlі dоnоrѕ whо ѕhаrе its gоаlѕ and vаluеѕ,<ref name=":0" /> including the Kraft Family ([[the Kraft Group]]), former Governor of Massachusetts [[Deval Patrick]], Hаnі Alаmі, a Palestinian telecommunications еntrерrеnеur, and Aron Ain, сhіеf еxесutіvе of [[Kronos Incorporated]]. Former Governor [[Deval Patrick]] ([[Massachusetts]]) currently serves as the Chairman of the OGS Advisory Board, alongside [[Robert Kraft]] who serves as Honorary Chairman.
Our Gеnеrаtіоn Sреаkѕ has since lаunсhеd thrее ѕtаrtuрѕ in Jеruѕаlеm & Rаmаllаh as of September 2016, and expects to launch at least 3 to 4 each year.<ref name=":2" /> Each OGS startup receives seed funding from OGS to establish themselves in Israel and Palestine. Some of the startups have also raised funds independently of OGS.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/12/israel-bedouin-genetic-disease-family-doctor.html|title=Bedouin woman battles genetic diseases in Israel's Negev|date=2016-12-30|work=Al-Monitor|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-us}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richardbehar/2017/03/21/backed-by-big-wheels-a-boston-incubator-hooks-up-young-israelis-and-palestinians-to-launch-startups/#5655e0d46424|title=Backed By Big Wheels, A Boston Incubator Hooks Up Young Israelis And Palestinians To Launch Startups|last=Behar|first=Richard|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>
In February 2017, three OGS Fellows were featured on [[Forbes]] Israel's "[[Forbes 30 Under 30]]" list for their achievements.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.co.il/news/new.aspx?Pn6VQ=EG&0r9VQ=EIIJD|title=מפגש תרבויות: שלוש הצעירות שהקימו מיזם לצמצום מחלות גנטיות|website=פורבס ישראל|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>
In March 2017, [[Richard Behar]] wrote a feature-length article about OGS for Forbes, featuring OGS Alumni and network members.<ref name=":1" />
In May 2017, OGS was one of two winners of the [https://www.SBANE.org SBANE] Innovation Awards in the Non-profit Category.<ref>{{Citation|last=SBANE.org|title=SBANE Innovation Awards 2017 Winner: Our Generation Speaks|date=2017-05-24|url=https://vimeo.com/218827509|accessdate=2017-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sbane.org/blogs/sbane-announces-the-winners-of-the-2017-innovation-awards|title=SBANE Announces the Winners of the 2017 Innovation Awards|last=SemiColonWeb|website=www.sbane.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref>

'''Pieter Corbeels''' ([[Leuven]], 12 March 1755 – [[Tournai]], 21 June 1799) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] book printer and resistance leader. He was a founder of the Belgian based publishing company [[Brepols]]. He commanded part of the [[Duchy of Brabant|Brabantine]] forces during a revolt against the French Revolutionary regime known as the ''[[Peasants' War (1798)|Boerenkrijg]]'' ("Peasants' War"). For his role in the war he was executed.
==Service in Austrian Army==
Corbeels, was a corporal in the [[Austria]]n army. He fought in the rebel army of [[Jean-André van der Mersch]], who won the [[Battle of Turnhout (1789)|Battle of Turnhout]] against the Austrians in 1789. After the defeat of the [[Brabant Revolution]], he started a printing business in Leuven in 1790. He established his printing business in the Gommarushuis in the Tiensestraat in Leuven. Corbeels printed besides the ordinary, ordered printed papers, also a large number of inciting leaflets and almanacs. For this he was arrested by the French, on 28 November 1792, and transferred to [[Valenciennes]] in France. On 15 December 1792, he was released whereupon he resumed printing. In 1793 he moved into the house called ''Hertog van Brabant'' on the ''Grote Markt'' of Leuven. In 1796, he moved with his wife, Barbara Panz, and assistant, [[Philippus Jacobus Brepols]], to [[Turnhout]], where he was less impeded by the French. On 16 September 1797, his wife died and on 31 October he remarried with Joanna Antonia Servaes.
==Life in Turnhout and Peasants War==
Corbeels remarried while living in Turnhout, and he left Turnhout in the summer of 1798 as a leader of the ''Boerenkrijg'' also known as the [[Peasants' War (1798)]] against the French. <ref>http://historiek.net/de-boerenkrijg/8675/</ref> On 25 November 1798, he was caught in Postel and taken by the French, whereupon he ended up in the prison, and was executed, together with Albert Meulemans, on 21 June 1799 in Tournai.
His widow initially continued the printing business, together with Philippus Jacobus Brepols. But in 1800 he bought the business from her. The [[Brepols]] printing business in Turnhout, grew out of this.

{{marketing}} In marketing, '''promotion''' refers to any type of [[marketing communications|marketing communication]] used to inform or persuade target audiences of the relative merits of a product, service, brand or issue. The aim of promotion is to increase awareness, create interest, generate sales or create [[brand loyalty]]. It is one of the basic elements of the [[market mix]], which includes the four P's ,i.e., Product, Price, Place, Promotion.<ref>{{cite book|last=McCarthy|first=Jerome E.|title=Basic Marketing. A Managerial Approach |year=1964| publisher=Irwin| location=Homewood, IL|isbn=0256025339|pages=769}}</ref>
Promotion is also one of the elements in the [[promotional mix]] or promotional plan. These are [[personal selling]], [[advertising]], [[sales promotion]], [[direct marketing]] [[publicity]] and may also include [[event-driven marketing|event marketing]], [[exhibition]]s and trade shows.<ref name="Raj">{{cite book | author=Rajagopal | title=Marketing dynamics theory and practice | publisher=New Age International | location=New Delhi | year=2007 | isbn=978-81-224-2712-7 }}</ref> A promotional plan specifies how much attention to pay to each of the elements in the promotional mix, and what proportion of the budget should be allocated to each element.
Promotion covers the methods of communication that a marketer uses to provide information about its product. Information can be both verbal and visual.
==Etymology and usage==
The term, "promotion' derives from the Old French, ''promocion'' meaning to "move forward", "push onward" or to "advance in rank or position" which in turn, comes from the Latin, ''promotionem'' meaning "a moving forward". The word entered the English language in the 14th century. <ref>''Online Etymology Encyclopedia,'' <Online: {{cite web |url=https://www.etymonline.com/word/promotion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108174811/https://www.etymonline.com/word/promotion |archivedate=2018-01-08 |df= }}></ref>
The use of the term promotion to refer to "advertising or publicity" is very modern and is first recorded in 1925. <ref>Online Etymology Encyclopedia, <Online: {{cite web |url=https://www.etymonline.com/word/promotion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108174811/https://www.etymonline.com/word/promotion |archivedate=2018-01-08 |df= }}></ref> It may be a contraction of a related term, ''sales promotion,'' which is one element in the larger set of tools used in marketing communications. The terms, ''promotion'' and ''marketing communications'' can be used synonymously, but in practice, the latter is more widely used. <ref>Pickton, D. and Broderick, A. ''Integrated Marketing Communications,'' Harlow, Essex, Pearson, 2005, pp 4-5</ref>
==Purpose== There are three objectives of promotion. These are:<ref name="kurtz">{{cite book | last=Boone | first=Louis |last2= Kurtz|first2=David | title=Contemporary marketing | publisher=Dryden Press | location=Hinsdale, Ill | year=1974 | isbn=978-0-03-088518-1 | page=}}</ref> # To present information to consumers and others. # To increase [[demand]]. # To differentiate a product. The purpose of a promotion and thus its promotional plan can have a wide range, including: sales increases, new product acceptance, creation of [[brand equity]], [[positioning (marketing)|positioning]], competitive retaliations, or creation of a [[Corporate identity|corporate image]].<ref name=Raj/>
The term 'promotion' tends to be used internally by the marketing function. To the public or the market, phrases like "[[special offer]]" are more common. Examples of a fully integrated, long-term, and large-scale promotion are [[My Coke Rewards]] in the USA or [[Coke Zone]] in the UK and [[Pepsi Stuff]].
==Types== There have been different ways to promote a product in person or with different media. Both person and media can be either physically real or virtual/electronic.
===In a physical environment=== Promotions can be held in physical environments at special events such as [[concert]]s, festivals, [[trade show]]s, and in the field, such as in grocery or department stores. Interactions in the field allow immediate purchases. The purchase of a product can be [[incentive]] with [[discounts and allowances|discount]]s (i.e., coupons), free items, or a contest. This method is used to increase the sales of a given product. Interactions between the brand and the customer are performed by a [[brand ambassador]] or [[promotional model]] who represents the product in physical environments. Brand ambassadors or promotional models are hired by a [[marketing company]], which in turn is booked by the brand to represent the product or service. Person-to-person interaction, as opposed to media-to-person involvement, establishes connections that add another dimension to promotion. [[community building|Building a community]] through promoting goods and services can lead to [[brand loyalty]].
===Traditional media=== Examples of traditional media include print media such as [[newspaper]]s and magazines, electronic media such as radio and [[television]], and outdoor media such as banner or [[billboard]] advertisements. Each of these platforms provide ways for brands to reach consumers with advertisements.
=== Digital media ===
Digital media, which includes Internet, [[social networking]] and [[social media]] sites, is a modern way for brands to interact with consumers as it releases news, information and advertising from the technological limits of print and broadcast infrastructures.<ref>Mulhern, Frank (2009). "Integrated marketing communications: From media channels to digital connectivity". ''Journal of Marketing Communications'' '''15''' (2-3): 87.</ref> Digital media is currently the most effective way for brands to reach their consumers on a daily basis. Over 2.7 billion people are online globally, which is about 40% of the world's population.<ref>Hudson, Simon; Huang, Li; Roth, Martin S.; Madden, Thomas J. "The influence of social media interactions on consumer–brand relationships: A three-country study of brand perceptions and marketing</ref> 67% of all Internet users globally use social media.<ref>Hudson, Simon; Roth, Martin S.; Madden, Thomas J.; Hudson, Rupert (2015-04-01). "The effects of social media on emotions, brand relationship quality, and word of mouth: An empirical study of music festival attendees". ''Tourism Management'' '''47''': 68–76. {{doi|10.1016/j.tourman.2014.09.001}}.</ref>
[[Mass communication]] has led to modern marketing strategies to continue focusing on brand awareness, large distributions and heavy promotions.<ref>Mulhern, Frank (2009). "Integrated marketing communications: From media channels to digital connectivity". ''Journal of Marketing Communications'' '''15''' (2-3): 85. doi:10.1080/13527260902757506.</ref> The fast-paced environment of digital media presents new methods for promotion to utilize new tools now available through technology. With the rise of technological advances, promotions can be done outside of local contexts and across geographic borders to reach a greater number of potential consumers. The goal of a promotion is then to reach the most people possible in a time efficient and a cost efficient manner.
Social media, as a modern marketing tool, offers opportunities to reach larger audiences in an interactive way. These interactions allow for conversation rather than simply educating the customer. [[Facebook]], [[Snapchat]], [[Instagram]], [[Twitter]], [[Pinterest]], [[Google Plus]], [[Tumblr]], as well as alternate audio and media sites like [[SoundCloud]] and [[Mixcloud]] allow users to interact and promote music online with little to no cost. You can purchase and buy ad space as well as potential customer interactions stores as [[Like button|Likes]], Followers, and clicks to your page with the use of third parties. As a participatory media culture, social media platforms or social networking sites are forms of mass communication that, through media technologies, allow large amounts of product and distribution of content to reach the largest audience possible.<sup>[2]</sup> However, there are downsides to virtual promotions as servers, systems, and websites may crash, fail, or become overloaded with information. You also can stand risk of losing uploaded information and storage and at a use can also be effected by a number of outside variables.
Brands can explore different strategies to keep consumers engaged. One popular tool is branded entertainment, or creating some sort of social game for the user. The benefits of such a platform include submersing the user in the brand's content. Users will be more likely to absorb and not grow tired of advertisements if they are, for example, embedded in the game as opposed to a bothersome pop-up ad.<ref>Ashley, C., & Tuten, T. (2015). Creative Strategies in Social Media Marketing: An Exploratory Study of Branded Social Content and Consumer Engagement. ''Psychology & Marketing'', 32(1), 15-27.</ref>
[[Personalizing advertisements]] is another strategy that can work well for brands, as it can increase the likelihood that the brand will be anthropomorphized by the consumer. Personalization increases click-through intentions when data has been collected about the consumer.<ref name=":0">Aguirre, Elizabeth; Mahr, Dominik; Grewal, Dhruv; de Ruyter, Ko; Wetzels, Martin (2015-03-01). "Unraveling the Personalization Paradox: The Effect of Information Collection and Trust-Building Strategies on Online Advertisement Effectiveness". ''Journal of Retailing'' '''91''' (1): 34–49. doi:10.1016/j.jretai.2014.09.005.</ref>
Brands must navigate the line between effectively promoting their content to consumers on social media and becoming too invasive in consumers' lives. Vivid Internet ads that include devices such as [[animation]] might increase a user's initial attention to the ad. However, this may be seen as a distraction to the user if they are trying to absorb a different part of the site such as reading text.<ref>Celebi, Serra Inci. "How do motives affect attitudes and behaviors toward internet advertising and Facebook advertising?". ''[[Computers in Human Behavior]]'' '''51''': 312–324. doi:10.1016/j.chb.2015.05.011.</ref> Additionally, when brands make the effort of overtly collecting data about their consumers and then personalizing their ads to them, the consumer's relationship with the advertisements, following this data collection, is frequently positive. However, when data is covertly collected, consumers can quickly feel like the company betrayed their trust.<ref name=":0" /> It is important for brands to utilize personalization in their ads, without making the consumer feel vulnerable or that their [[internet privacy|privacy]] [[privacy breach|has been betrayed]].

'''Sisense''' is a [[business analytics]] software company with offices in [[New York City]], [[Tel Aviv]], and [[Scottsdale, Arizona]]. Its [[business intelligence]] product includes both a back-end powered by in-chip technology that enables non-technical users to join and analyze [[big data|large data sets]] from multiple sources,<ref name=ForbesMarch13 /> and a front-end for creating [[data visualization|visualizations]], like dashboards and reports, on any device, including mobile.<ref name=IncJune13 /><ref name=NextWebApril13 /><ref name=FierceOct12 /><ref name=DataInformedAugust12 /><ref name=GigaomApril13 /><ref name=NocamelsApril13 />
== History == Sisense was founded in 2004 in Tel Aviv by Elad Israeli, Eldad Farkash, Aviad Harell, Guy Boyangu and Adi Azaria.<ref name=Haaretz /> The company worked in stealth mode on research and development until 2010, when initial investors, including [[Genesis Partners]], [[Opus Capital]] and Eli Farkash, provided $4 million in [[Series A round|Series A financing]].<ref name=Haaretz /><ref name=CrunchBase />
Amit Bendov was appointed CEO in July 2012.<ref name=SVBJ12 /> In April 2013, Sisense announced a $10 million [[Series B round|series B funding round]] led by [[Battery Ventures]], with participation from Genesis Partners and Opus Capital. In June 2014, new investor [[Draper Fisher Jurvetson]] Growth (DFJ Growth) led a $30 million series C funding round with participation from existing investors Battery Ventures, Genesis Partners and Opus Capital.<ref name=TechCrunchJune14 /><ref name=WSJjune14 />
In February 2013, as the first company in [[TechCrunch#CrunchBase|CrunchBase's]] "Developer Spotlight Program,"<ref name="ForbesMarch13" /> Sisense analyzed 10 years of CrunchBase data in a public interactive investment dashboard dubbed CrunchAnalytics.<ref name="SisenseCB" /> By analyzing a decade's worth of data about 100,000 companies, the dashboard provides the public with a research tool that enables users to query the data by different categories to see trends in investment over the past ten years.<ref name="ForbesMarch13" />
In 2015, Amir Orad was appointed CEO. Orad previously served as CEO of [[NICE Actimize]].<ref name="EnterpriseappstodayMarch2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.enterpriseappstoday.com/business-intelligence/startup-spotlight-sisenses-big-data-analytics.html|title=Startup Spotlight: Sisense’s Big Data Analytics|last=All|first=Ann|date=20 March 2015|work=Enterprise Apps Today}}</ref><ref name="GeektimeMarch2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.geektime.com/2015/03/23/from-a-145m-exit-to-ceo-of-sisense-amir-orad-could-lead-this-big-data-company-to-a-grand-future/|title=From a $145M exit to CEO of Sisense, Amir Orad could lead this big data company to a grand future|last=Weinglas|first=Simona|date=March 23, 2015|work=Geek Time}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.geektime.com/2015/03/23/from-a-145m-exit-to-ceo-of-sisense-amir-orad-could-lead-this-big-data-company-to-a-grand-future/|title=From a $145M exit to CEO of Sisense, Amir Orad could lead this big data company to a grand future|date=2015-03-23|work=Geektime|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref> In January 2016, the company announced a new $50 million funding round led by [[Bessemer Venture Partners]], with participation by Battery Ventures, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Genesis Partners and Opus Capital.<ref name="WSJJan16">{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2016/01/07/under-new-ceo-sisense-raises-50m/|title=Under New CEO, Sisense Raises $50M|last=Gage|first=Deborah|date=January 7, 2016|work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
The company's software is used by companies in 49 countries.<ref name="NextWebApril13" /> Customers include [[Target Corporation|Target]].<ref name="WSJnov12" /> In February 2018, the company was listed as a Visionary on the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Analytics and Business Intelligence Platforms.<ref name="Gartner18" />
In September 2018, the company announced another $80 million funding round led by Insight Venture Partners.<ref name="80funding" />
== Technology == In April 2013, Sisense introduced an alternative to [[in-memory database|in-memory technology]] called In-Chip analytics,<ref name=InfoNov13 /> designed to maximize the disk, memory and CPU with resulting low latency.<ref name=GigaomApril13 />
In May 2013, Sisense unveiled Prism 10X, which allows users to analyze 100 times more data at 10 times the speed of in-memory solutions. The company’s In-Chip Analytics technology couples a columnar database with smart algorithms that use the in-chip cache, RAM or disk as needed instead of relying solely on RAM or disk.<ref name=KDNuggetsMay13 /><ref name=BusinessIntelligenceNov13 />
In October 2013, Sisense introduced Crowd Accelerated BI,<ref name=BusinessIntelligenceNov13 /> a technology that allows companies to scale users by providing faster query results as load increases and scale to thousands of simultaneous users on a single box.<ref name=DataNamiOct13 /><ref name=DatabaseOct13 />
Each query is broken down to its basic components, which then helps the software decide which data to store on disk and which data to bring to memory. As more queries are catalogued, the software is able to more quickly recognize future similar queries and call up relevant data.<ref name=ForbesOct13 />
In April 2017, Sisense introduced Sisense Pulse which provides alert when it detects results outside of normal parameters for a particular metric.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/04/12/sisense-pulse-uses-machine-learning-to-trigger-data-anomaly-alerts/|title=Sisense Pulse uses machine learning to trigger data anomaly alerts – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== * 2017 - Best Business Intelligence Tool and Platform in the 32nd annual ''SIIA CODiE'' Awards<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170727006261/en/Sisense-Recognized-Software-Information-Industry-Association-SIIA/|title=Sisense Recognized by the Software & Information Industry Association (SIIA) as Best Business Intelligence Tool and Platform|website=businesswire.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>

Noted as the world's largest startup facility.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Medeiros|first1=João|title=Station F, the world's largest startup campus opens in Paris|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/station-f|accessdate=21 August 2017|work=Wired|date=29 June 2017}}</ref>
Situated in a former rail freight depot previously known as la [[Halle Freyssinet]] (thereof the "F" in Station F). The 34,000 m<sup>2</sup> facility was formally opened by President [[Emmanuel Macron]] in June 2017 and provides office accommodation for up to 1,000 start-up and early stage businesses as well as for corporate partners such as Facebook, [[Microsoft]] and [[Naver]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Agnew|first1=Harriet|title=Technology: Macron thinks big in his vision for French unicorns|url=https://www.ft.com/content/61c5f20a-81a8-11e7-a4ce-15b2513cb3ff|accessdate=21 August 2017|work=Financial Times|date=20 August 2017}}</ref>

As well as 3,000 desk spaces and private meeting facilities, the incubator also hosts a 370-seat auditorium and dining facilities open to the public. Facebook's own Startup Garage in the building will host up to 15 companies on a six monthly cycle and represents the company's first physical space dedicated to startups.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burgess|first1=Matt|title=More than 100 entrepreneurs sign up to help Facebook and Station F find the best startups|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/station-f-facebook-startup-garage-startups|accessdate=21 August 2017|work=Wired|date=1 February 2017}}</ref>
